hedline.hl1: Memories of Carnivals As a Child's Playground

abstract.p: Ellen Kelly McGee letter on June 25 article on carnivals recalls Catholic school fund-raising carnivals of her childhood (S)

block.p: I enjoyed ''The Carnival's Coming to Town'' (cover, June 25) for the memories it stirred of traveling carnivals I attended while a little girl. In my neighborhood, the chief fund-raising event of the year for several Catholic schools was a spring carnival.

I enjoyed ''The Carnival's Coming to Town'' (cover, June 25) for the memories it stirred of traveling carnivals I attended while a little girl. In my neighborhood, the chief fund-raising event of the year for several Catholic schools was a spring carnival.

In the school I attended, we would spy out the windows, during classes on frog dissecting and pre-algebra, to view the formation of giant Tilt-a-Whirls and cobra roller coasters and the setting up of colorful tents and games.

Classes would conclude early one day and the carnival gates would open only to school students for a few magical hours. It was a financial gain to the school and a memory-making gain for the children.

In our present-day society of insurance nightmares and legal liabilities, none of the schools in our area use a carnival as a source of money-raising. As a teacher, if I were asked to release students to the thrills of a carnival playground, I would shudder and voice my hesitation. But as I remember the delights of those spring days, I can only wish for the carnival's return.
